snippet: A NATO report based on interrogations portrays an insurgency convinced it is winning even as the United States and its allies enter what they hope will be the Afghan war’s final phase.
abstract: NATO report based on interrogations of Taliban captives portrays an insurgency convinced it is winning the Afghanistan war even as the United States and its allies enter what they hope will be the war’s final phase; Taliban say they are converting growing number of Afghan government officials and soldiers; report provides a sobering counterpoint to the coalition's more upbeat public assessments of progress in the war.

byline.original: By ROD NORDLAND and ALISSA J. RUBIN
byline.contributor: Reporting was contributed by Declan Walsh and Salman Masood from Islamabad, Pakistan; Sharifullah Sahak from Kabul; and Steven Lee Myers from Washington.

lead_paragraph: A NATO report based on interrogations portrays an insurgency convinced it is winning even as the United States and its allies enter what they hope will be the Afghan war’s final phase.

headline.seo: NATO Plays Down Optimistic Views of Taliban Captives
headline.main: Taliban Captives Dispute U.S. View on Afghanistan War
headline.print_headline: Taliban Captives Dispute U.S. View On State Of War
